document.docAuthor: ShinK, Jong Hak & LeeK, Jimin & ChangK, Cheon Young
document.docTitle: A new species of Agauopsis (Acari, Halacaridae) from South Korea belonging to A. brevipalpus group

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Agauopsis (Acari, Halacaridae) from South Korea belonging to A. brevipalpus group

emphasis.docTitle:
A new species of
Agauopsis
( Acari , Halacaridae ) from South Korea belonging to
A . brevipalpus
group

subSection.paragraph:
Jong Hak Shin K
a
,
Jimin Lee K
b
,
Cheon Young Chang K
a

paragraph.docAuthorAffiliation: Department of Biomedical Science, Daegu University, Gyeongsan 38453, Korea .
Ocean Climate Response Íûè Ecosystem Research Department, Korea Institute of Ocean Science and Technology, Busan 49111, Korea .

subSection.paragraph:
A new marine halacarid mite of the genus
Agauopsis Viets, 1927
is recorded from mussels

in the intertidal bedrock of the southern coast of South Korea .
Agauopsis bisetosa
n.

sp. belonging to the
A. brevipalpus
group, is characterized by an ‚ÄòH‚Äô-shaped areola on the anterior dorsal plate, two pairs of costae on the posterior dorsal plate, a tectum with
a truncate anterior margin, posterior epimeral plate with two ventral setae, telofemur

I with one ventral and two ventromedial dentate spines, and tibia II with one ventral and one ventromedial dentate spines. Notably, the presence of two ventral setae on the posterior epimeral plate is a unique characteristic of the new species. This study deals with a description of
A. bisetosa
n. sp. , accompanied by detailed illustrations drawn under a differential interference contrast microscope and scanning electron microscope photomicrographs. Additionally, it includes a character comparison table of the
A. brevipalpus
group and a key for known
Agauopsis species
in the northwest Pacific, both including the new species.

Keywords
Agauopsis bisetosa
new species
Õæ marine Õæ meiofauna Õæ Pacific Õæ taxonomy

Zoobank http://zoobank.org/
81D43216-92C9-46BB-A72D-62922135F518

The genus
Agauopsis Viets, 1927
currently comprises 90 valid species, accounting for 7.6% of all species in the family Halacaridae . It is the third most diverse genus after
Copidognathus Trouessart, 1888
with 380 species (32.2%) and
Rhombognathus Trouessart, 1888
with 110 species (9.3%) ( Bartsch 2015a Õæ WoRMS 2023). In this genus, 79 species are allocated to

seven different species groups: the
brevipalpus
,
conjuncta
,
furcata
,
microrhyncha
,
okinavensis
,
ornata
, and
pugio
( Bartsch 1986a ,
1996 a
, 2005, 2015a Õæ Bartsch and Iliffe 1985 Õæ
Chatterjee et al. 2009
Õæ Macquitty 1983 ), and the remaining 11 species have not yet been clearly identified as part of any specific group. Among these groups, the
brevipalpus
group is the most species-rich group, comprising 25 species ( Bartsch 2015a ).

In the northwest Pacific region, 14
Agauopsis species
have been documented to date:
A. robusta Sokolov, 1952
from the Russian coast of Sea of Japan ( Sokolov 1952 )Õæ
A . pseudoornata Bartsch, 1985
from Philippines (Bartsch 1985)Õæ
A . okinavensis Bartsch, 1986
from Japan ( Bartsch 1986a )Õæ
A . ammodytes Bartsch, 1992
,
A . arenaria Bartsch, 1992
,
A . humilis Bartsch, 1992
, and
A . sordida Bartsch, 1992
from Hong Kong ( Bartsch 1992a , 1992b )Õæ
A . arborea Bartsch, 2003
,
A . dissimilis Bartsch 2015
,
A . longirostris Bartsch, 2015
,
A . moorea Bartsch, 1992
, and
A . sordida
from Singapore ( Bartsch 2015a , 2015b )Õæ
A . ivanomorsellii Chatterjee & Chang, 2007
,
A . tetrasetosa Shin & Chang, 2019
and
A . youngilensis Chatterjee & Chang, 2007
from South Korea ( Chatterjee and Chang 2007 Õæ Shin and Chang 2019 ). Among them, only seven species belong to the
brevipalpus
group:
A . arborea
,
A . dissimilis
,
A . ivanomorsellii
,
A . longirostris
,
A . moorea
,
A . sordida
, and
A . youngilensis
.

This study deals with a new species of
Agauopsis
belonging to the
brevipalpus
group collected from mussels in the intertidal rocky shores on the southern coast of Korea , based on detailed illustrations and scanning electron microscope photographs of both females and males. Additionally, we provide a character comparison table of the
A . brevipalpus
group in the genus
Agauopsis
as well as a key to the 15
Agauopsis species
known in the northwest Pacific.

Halacarid mites were collected from clumped mussels
Mytilus
(sp.) on rocks in the intertidal
zone. Specimens were obtained by immersing the mussels in a bucket of tap water for
approximately 10 minutes to induce osmotic shock, and rinsing through a nylon net (64 Œºm in
pore diameter). Filtered specimens were immediately fixed with 80% ethanol or 5% formalin.
Detailed methods for preparing slide specimens and creating illustrations are referenced from

Lee et al. (2023)
, and scanning electron microscopy follows Lee and Chang (2017) . Scale bars
in the figures are in ¬µm.
Type specimens are deposited at the Honam National Institute of Biological Resources
(HNIBR), Mokpo, Korea .
Terminology and abbreviations in the text and figure captions follow Bartsch (2006) : AD,
anterior dorsal plateÕæ AE, anterior epimeral plateÕæ ds, dorsal setae on idiosoma (ds-1 to ds-6,
first to sixth dorsal setae on idiosoma)Õæ GA, genitoanal plateÕæ glp, gland pore(s), numbered
glp-1 to glp-2 from anterior to posteriorÕæ GO, genital openingÕæ OC, ocular plate(s)Õæ P, palp (P-1
to P-4, first to fourth palpal segments)Õæ pas, parambulacral setaeÕæ PD , posterior dorsal plateÕæ PE,
posterior epimeral plateÕæ pgs, perigenital setaeÕæ sgs, subgenital setae.

subSubSection.paragraph: Zoobank: 9E2A5B99-D7E7-4AF0-8D93-B5FB2E1ADA42
( Figures 1 ‚Äì4)

Type locality
‚Äî Korea : Jeollanam-do , Yeosu-si, Sindeok-dong, Sindeok beach ( 34¬∞49‚Ä≤05 ∫N , 127¬∞46‚Ä≤01 ∫E ), mussels (
Mytilus sp.
) attached to rocks, 0‚àí0.5 m depth, 19 Aug. 2018 , Shin J.H.

Type material ‚Äî Holotype : ‚ôÄ (HNIBRIV11667), mounted in glycerin on H-S slide, from the type locality. Paratypes : ‚ôÇ ( allotype , HNIBRIV11668) and 5‚ôÄ‚ôÄ , 4‚ôÇ‚ôÇ (HNIBRIV11669‚Äì 11677) mounted in glycerin on H-S slide from the type locality.
Additional material examined ‚Äî 5‚ôÄ‚ôÄ , 5‚ôÇ‚ôÇ on a stub for SEM, same data as for holotype .

Etymology ‚Äî The specific name,
bisetosa
, refers to ‚Äòtwo‚Äô ventral ‚Äòsetae‚Äô on the posterior epimeral plate, the unique feature of the new species.

Description of female ( holotype )
‚Äî Idiosoma ( Figures 1A and 3A) 453 ¬µm long (449‚Äì521 ¬µm, mean = 471 ¬µm, n = 6), 320 ¬µm wide (317‚Äì401 ¬µm, mean = 346 ¬µm, n = 6), length to

long as idiosoma, 160 ¬µm wide (152‚Äì175 ¬µm, mean = 165 ¬µm, n = 6), length to width ratio 0.93Õæ triangular-shaped, rounded posterolaterally, and concave medially at posterior marginÕæ ‚ÄòH‚Äô-shaped areola protuberant (Figure 3C), decorated with 2‚àí3 polygonal porose panels wideÕæ each porose panels with 6‚àí12 canaliculi (Figure 3D)Õæ anterior part of transverse ridge of ‚ÄòH‚Äô-shaped areola much shorter than rear partÕæ pair of glp-1 located at anteromedial end of anterior arms of ‚ÄòH‚Äô-shaped areola.

as idiosoma, 116 ¬µm wide (112‚Äì125 ¬µm, mean = 120 ¬µm, n = 6), length to width ratio 0.53Õæ narrowing posteriorly and pointed distallyÕæ posterior end extending near insertion of leg IIIÕæ each with 2 corneae on raised transverse areola laterallyÕæ areola covered with 9‚àí11 polygonal porose panelsÕæ glp-2 and pore canaliculi located at posterolateral to posterior cornea.
PD ( Figures 1A and 3E) 238 ¬µm long (236‚Äì257 ¬µm, mean = 247 ¬µm, n = 6), about 0.53
times as long as idiosoma, 218 ¬µm wide (211‚Äì227 ¬µm, mean = 221 ¬µm, n = 6), length to width
ratio 1.09Õæ anterior margin almost truncateÕæ narrowest at anterior 18% of PD , approximately

0.52 times as wide as PD Õæ with 2 pairs of longitudinal costae, medial costae more distinct than lateral onesÕæ medial costae gradually close to each other towards posterior margin, and each costa with 2‚àí3 polygonal porose panels wideÕæ each lateral costa narrow, with 1‚àí2 polygonal porose panels wideÕæ porose panels on costae consisting of 7‚àí14 canaliculiÕæ remaining area of
PD covered with canaliculi (Figure 3F).

Dorsal setae ( Figure 1A ): ds-1 situated at anterior 38% of ADÕæ ds-2 on membranous cuticle anterior to OCÕæ ds-3 on membranous cuticle among AD, OC, and PD Õæ 3 pairs of dorsal setae (ds-4, ds-5, and ds-6) at anterior 22%, 55%, and 100% of PD , respectively, of which anterior two (ds-4 and ds-5) situated at lateral edge of raised medial costae, ds-6 at posterior margin of PD .
All ventral plates ( Figures 1B and 3B) well-developed and separated by membranous cuticle, and just as dorsal plates covered with small pores.
¬µm, mean = 322 ¬µm, n = 6), length to width ratio 0.64Õæ posterior margin straight or weakly convexÕæ with 3 pairs of ventral setaeÕæ a pair of epimeral pores present near trochanter IIÕæ 2 pairs
of lyrifissures (= pore canaliculi) located consecutively posterior to epimeral pores.

AE, 207 ¬µm wide (201‚Äì218 ¬µm, mean = 212 ¬µm, n = 6), length to width ratio 0.83Õæ anterior margin almost straight or slightly convexÕæ distance from anterior margin of GO to that of GA, 40 ¬µm, about 0.45 times length of GOÕæ with 3 pairs of pgs located at anterior 23%, 53% and

67% of GA, respectively, foremost seta at the level similar to anterior end of GO, second pgs at the level of half of GO, and last seta at posterolateral margin of GO, both second and last setae close to GOÕæ sgs absent. GO 89 ¬µm long, about 0.52 times as long as GA.
0.29 times as long as idiosoma, 76 ¬µm wide (74‚Äì80 ¬µm, mean = 78 ¬µm, n = 6), length to

width ratio 1.72Õæ dorsal and ventral surface covered with punctate poresÕæ with 4 pairs of setae, consisting of 3 pairs of setae on rostrum and 1 pair of setae on gnathosomal baseÕæ protorostral and deutorostral setae situated at tip of rostrum, tritorostral setae at anterior 20% of rostrum ventrally, and basirostral setae at anterior 15% of gnathosomal baseÕæ gnathosomal base about 2.05 times length of rostrum. Rostrum 43 ¬µm long, 0.33 times as long as gnathosoma, its tip slightly reaching beyond end of P-3. Palp ( Figures 2A, B and 4C) consisting of 4 segments, their lengths 7, 28, 9, and 9 ¬µm, respectivelyÕæ P-1 without setaeÕæ P-2 longest, with 1 dorsodistal setaÕæ P-3 with 1 dentate spine (9 ¬µm long, equal to length of P-3) mediallyÕæ P-4 with 1 long dorsal and 1 short ventral setae proximally, and 3 spinelets at its distal end. Tectum truncated

Telofemur I armed with 1 ventral and 2 ventromedial bidentate spines. Genu I with 1 ventral and 1 ventromedial bidentate spines. Tibia I with 1 ventral and

Tarsi I‚ÄìIV 48, 55, 69, and 71 ¬µm long, respectivelyÕæ tarsus I ( Figure 2C, G ) with 3 dorsal, 2 ventral setae, 1 ventromedial bidentate spine, 1 tiny solenidion (indicated by arrowhead in Figure 2G ), and a pair of doublet eupathid pasÕæ tarsus I with a pair of smooth lateral claws, and bidentate median clawÕæ tarsus II ( Figures 2D, H and 4D) armed with 3 dorsal setae, 1 tiny solenidion, 1 lateral doublet (consisting of

1 eupathid and 1 short spinelet) and 1 medial spinelet pasÕæ tarsi III‚ÄìIV ( Figure 2E, F ) with 3 dorsal setae and 1 lateral spinelet pas, respectivelyÕæ tarsi II‚ÄìIV, each with a dorsal accessory process and 6‚Äì7 teeth on either side of curved area on lateral claw ( Figures 2H and 4D), and without median claw.
5), 370 ¬µm wide (362‚Äì401 ¬µm, mean = 382 ¬µm, n = 5). Similar to female, except for genital region. GA ( Figures 1D and 4A, B) 197 ¬µm long (188‚Äì206 ¬µm, mean = 198 ¬µm, n = 5), 0.98
times as long as AE, 221 ¬µm wide (217‚Äì230 ¬µm, mean = 224 ¬µm, n = 5), length to width ratio

0.89Õæ anterior margin concaveÕæ armed with 41 pgs, a pair of outlying pgs located at anterior 17% of GA, and 39 pgs arranged in two rows around GO (with a range of 36‚Äì42 pgs)Õæ with 5 pairs of sgs on genital sclerite, 2 pairs at anterior part and 3 pairs at posterior part, of which fourth sgs (14 ¬µm long) larger than others (8 ¬µm long) ( Figures 1E and 4B). GO 84 ¬µm long, about 0.43 times as long as GAÕæ distance from anterior margin of GO to that of GA, 55 ¬µm long, about 0.65 times length of GO. Spermatopositor large, its anterior end reaching to the level of insertion of leg III.

Remarks ‚Äî Considering the classification by Bartsch (2015a) ,
A. bisetosa
n. sp.
evidently belongs to the
A. brevipalpus
group with 25 congeners, and is characterized by the following combination of characters: AD with an ‚ÄòH‚Äô-shaped areolaÕæ PE with two ventral setaeÕæ P-4 with two basal setae and three apical spineletsÕæ telofemur I with one ventral and two ventromedial dentate spinesÕæ and tibia II with one ventral and one ventromedial dentate spines.

In the
brevipalpus
group, the number of dentate spines serves as a highly valuable feature for easy identification ( Bartsch 2015a ). Notably, eight species including the new species, exhibit three dentate spines on telofemur I:
A . newelli Krantz, 1973
and
A . filirostris Macquitty,

1983 from U.S.A. Õæ
A . reticulatus Newell, 1984
from Chile Õæ
A . luxtoni Bartsch, 1986
and
A . novaezelandiae Bartsch, 1986
from New Zealand Õæ
A . ivanomorsellii
from Korea Õæ and
A . glabra Bartsch, 2009
from Australia ( Bartsch 1986b , 2009 Õæ Chatterjee and Chang 2007 Õæ Krantz 1973 Õæ Macquitty 1983 Õæ Newell 1984 ). Among them,
A . bisetosa
n. sp.
is closely allied with
A . ivanomorsellii
and
A . luxtoni
in sharing a short frontal process, the presence of an ‚ÄòH‚Äô-shaped areola on the AD, and two pairs of costae on the PD . However, the new species is distinguishable from them by the following characteristics ( Table 1 ): (1) ds-4 is located on the PD in the new species and
A . ivanomorsellii
, whereas it is positioned on the membranous cuticle at the front

of the PD in
A . luxtoni
Õæ (2) PE has two ventral setae in the new species, while three ventral

setae are present in
A . ivanomorsellii
and
A . luxtoni
Õæ (3) the length ratio of rostrum/gnathosoma

is 33% in the new species, whereas it is 45% and 40% in
A . ivanomorsellii
and
A . luxtoni
, respectivelyÕæ (4) P-4 possesses three apical spinelets in the new species, while two spinelets

tr.td:
are present in
A . ivanomorsellii
and
A . luxtoni
Õæ and (5) the number of spines on tibiae II‚ÄìIV is

2-1-1 spines in the new species and
A . luxtoni
, whereas
A . ivanomorsellii
has 3-2-2 spines.
In general, halacarid mites have one dorsal (or lateral) and three ventral setae on the PE
( Ab√© 1998 Õæ Green and Macquitty 1987 Õæ Newell 1984 ). Despite the same is true within the genus

tr.th:
Figure 4
Agauopsis bisetosa
n. sp.
, SEM photographs. A, B, male: A ‚Äì Habitus, ventralÕæ B ‚Äì GO with pgs. C, D, female: C ‚Äì P-3 and P-4, ventralÕæ D ‚Äì Tip of tarsus II, medial.

tr.td:
Agauopsis
, it is reduced to one or two setae in rare cases. In the genus
Agauopsis
, two species,

A. bacescui Konnerth-Ionescu, 1977
and
A. crassipes ( Gimbel, 1920 )
, belonging to the
ornata

and
microrhyncha
groups, respectively, have been recorded as bearing two ventral setae on

PE ( Gimbel 1920 Õæ Konnerth-Ionescu 1977). In the
brevipalpus
group,
A. bisetosa
n. sp.
is the

sole species with two ventral setae on the PE. As for another member of the
brevipalpus
group,

A . glabra, Bartsch (2009)
described two ventral setae on PE for the female holotype, whereas

three for one female and one male paratypes. Furthermore, in the holotype of
A. glabra
, the

position of the two ventral setae on PE are different from that of
A. bisetosa
n. sp.
: the rear seta

locates near the coxal insertion of leg IV in
A. glabra
, while ventromedial corner of PE at the
level of insertion of leg III in the new species (indicated by an arrowhead in Figure 1B).

Agauopsis ivanomorsellii
and
A . youngilensis
, both of which are recorded in Korea and

belong to the
brevipalpus
group as
A. bisetosa
n. sp.
is, exhibit distinct morphological

differences from the new species. The morphological differences between
A. ivanomorsellii

and
A. bisetosa
n. sp.
have been already stated above. Besides the unique characteristic of

ventral setae on the PE,
A. bisetosa
n. sp.
is discernible from
A . youngilensis
as follows: (1)

td.emphasis:
Key to the species of
Agauopsis
recorded from the northwest Pacific

tr.td:
Below is a dichotomous key for known
Agauopsis species
from the northeast Pacific, including the new species from this study.

1. Palp with longest fourth segment (P-4)Õæ P-3 with a long medial seta...........................................................................
A . okinavensis
(
okinavensis
group) ‚Äî Palp with longest second segment (P-2)Õæ P-3 with a medial spine....................... 2
2. Idiosoma with five pairs of dorsal setae.............................................. 3 ‚Äî Idiosoma with six pairs of dorsal setae............................................... 5

3. OC with two corneaeÕæ AE with garland-like areolae.......
A . pseudoornata
(
ornata
group) ‚Äî OC without corneaÕæ AE without areola................................ 4 (
furcata
group)

4. AD as long as OC lengthÕæ telofemur I with one spine......................
A . ammodytes
‚Äî AD longer than OCÕæ telofemur I with three spines...........................
A . arenaria

5. P-3 with a pointed spineÕæ tibia I with one ventral and three ventromedial spines, of which two ventromedial spines adjacent to each other.....................6 (
microrhyncha
group) ‚Äî P-3 with a blunted spineÕæ tibia I with one ventral and two ventromedial spines.............................................................................. 8 (
brevipalpus
group)

6. Ds-4 located on membranous cuticle between OC and PDÕæ palp shorter than rostrum...... .............................................................................
A . humilis

subSection.paragraph: ‚Äî Ds-4 located on PD Õæ palp longer than rostrum........................................ 7

A . robusta

tetrasetosa

9. Tibia II with three spinesÕæ tibiae III‚àíIV each with one ventral spine......
A . bisetosa
n. sp.
‚Äî Tibia II with four spinesÕæ tibiae III‚àíIV with two ventral spines...........
A . ivanomorsellii

10. AD with ‚ÄòM‚Äô-shaped areolaÕæ ds-4 located on PD ....................... A ..
youngilensis
‚Äî AD with ‚ÄòH‚Äô-shaped areolaÕæ ds-4 located on membranous cuticle between OC and PD ... 11
11. Tibia II with two ventral spinesÕæ tibia III without spines............................. 12 ‚Äî Tibia II with three ventral spinesÕæ tibia III with two ventral spines..................... 13

12. Rostrum as long as gnathosomal baseÕæ P-4 with one basal seta.............. A ..
dissimilis
‚Äî Rostrum shorter than gnathosomal base longÕæ P-4 with two basal setae....... A ..
arborea

13. Gnathosoma 2.1‚àí2.3 times longer than wideÕæ basifemur IV with one seta...
A . longirostris
‚Äî Gnathosoma 1.8‚àí1.9 times longer than wideÕæ basifemur IV with two setae............. 14

14. Tectum with scaliform lamellaÕæ male with 30 pgsÕæ AE with polygonal porose panels consisting of 6‚àí8 canaliculi...................................................
A . moorea

‚Äî Tectum with slightly arched lamellaÕæ male with 35‚Äì47 pgsÕæ AE with polygonal porose panels consisting of 10‚àí15 canaliculi.................................................
A . sordida

This research was supported by a Daegu University Research Grant, 2019.
